questions.q: The U.S. government does not need a warrant to snoop through your personal emails or even GPS you anywhere.
questions.correct:
Totally true. Thanks to ancient legislation (“updated” in 1986), the government is free to pick through your inbox and read anything older than 180 days without asking anyone (especially you). They can even request cell phone carriers to ping your exact location.

Help ECPA (Electronic Communications Privacy Act) get with the times here.

questions.q: It’s impossible to fact-check the news, that’s crazy talk!
questions.correct: False, false, false. While many news sources have distinct POVs (liberal, conservative, satire…) and some stories are more opinion than anything, sites like NewsTrust and ProPublica are great resources to help you filter the facts from all the fluff.

questions.q: Internet savvy, social-media-minded folks under 30 are WAY more likely to trick out their privacy settings on sites like Facebook and Twitter than users who are “over the hill.”
questions.correct: Very true! According to a 2010 study, a whopping 71% of users 18-29 have adjusted their privacy settings to limit what they share. Meanwhile, only 55% of users 50-64 year old (cough, cough, your parents) do the same. You guys in the know are also more likely to delete any comments or photos that could jeopardize your chances of being president (you go!) …or just reveal embarrassing stuff to the folks in HR.

questions.q: It's impossible to discover the motives or slant behind a news source.
questions.correct: So false. There are simple questions you can ask to determine where a source is coming from, whether it’s your friend’s passive aggressive status update or breaking news. You can use this and other tools to uncover the hidden messages within the media and recognize what they really want you to believe.

questions.q: When deciding if a website is legit, it’s important to notice the “little things,” like the way information is presented visually, and how often it’s updated.
questions.correct: You know it’s true. The little things can point to big problems with a source’s credibility. Find out which warning signs to look for here.

questions.q: Even though a warrant isn’t legally required, there are some companies that are asking the government to prove probable cause before just handing over a user’s personal info.
questions.correct: True! But how can they do that? Well, in 2010, the 6th court of appeals said that a little thing called our constitution protects the personal information that we share with a 3rd party provider. While many big-name companies have taken this to heart and begun asking for warrants, the ruling fell short of setting a precedent that would apply everywhere. Find out who has your back here.

questions.q: Most peeps under 30 are turning off the TV and turning to digital for all their news needs.
questions.correct: Yup, it's true! Newspapers, radio and even TV are so yesterday. According to a 2012 study, over 60% of people 18-29 prefer to get their news from a variety of digital platforms, including online, email, social media, podcasts and more.

questions.q: Most digital natives (you know, people under 35) are comfortable with others having access to your personal data online.
questions.correct: That is very, very false. According to a 2013 study, while more people under 35 are willing to share personal information than their parents’ generation, a 70% majority still say “hands off.” Don’t believe that link? Good, you’re starting to question your sources. Here’s another.

questions.q: Men dominate the news. In 2010, women were heard, seen, or interviewed only 25% of the time.
questions.correct: True! According to the Global Media Monitoring Project, women are drastically underrepresented as newsmakers, experts, and even as subject matter in news stories. You can help mainstream media catch up to modern times here

questions.q: If I can’t even access my personal info without my username and password, no one can.
questions.correct: Seriously false. As this graphic shows, some sites play pretty loose with their users’ info. A 2011 study found that 56% of 100 popular websites leaked personal data about their users to third parties (ever wonder why you’re starting to see ads for stuff you might actually want?).
